clinical_study.brief_title: Perception of Baby's Painful Cry in fMRI
clinical_study.official_title: Perception of Baby's Painful Cry: Investigation in fMRI to Neuronal Activity Related to Empathy in Adults

lead_sponsor.agency: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Saint Etienne

clinical_study.source: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Saint Etienne

brief_summary.textblock: Crying is the primary signaling strategy available to the human newborn for eliciting parental care. Yet, the investigators only have superficial understanding of the information carried by cries, and how this information is perceived by parents. Using modern tools of sound processing and functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) experiment, this study aims to investigate cry-induced brain activation in adult depending on the cry's acoustic properties expressing various degrees of stress and distress levels. For that, Adults will be tested inside a fMRI magnet to determine their brain activations elicited by different babies cries according to whether the cry was evoked in a pain situation or not. The cerebral activity will be investigated in relation to acoustic features of cries (e.g. with pitch and/or roughness variations). To test if the gender or parentally of adult listeners influence their perceptions and brain responses, the task will be applied to 2 different groups (men and women not-parents). The hypothesis is that the brain of adult listeners will be able to discriminate adequately the intensity of the pain mediated by the cries. This process should involve brain areas such as the insular and the orbito frontal cortex that are known to participate in the integration of pain intensity and pain controls. The experiment should also determine which one of the acoustic features is able to transmit pain and to recruit brain areas involved in pain processes.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: 20 men and 20 women : group "non parent" 20 father and 20 mother : group "parent"

primary_outcome.description: Measure of blood-oxygen-level dependent with fMRI during listening to natural crying.

secondary_outcome.description: Measure of blood-oxygen-level dependent with by fMRI during listening to artificial crying.

secondary_outcome.measure: impact of gender and parenting on perception of baby's cry
secondary_outcome.description: Measure of blood-oxygen-level dependent with by fMRI during listening to artificial crying.

intervention.description: During fMRI, healthy volunteers will listen 80 baby's cry.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Man or woman aged between 18 and 50
- Contact-less with children
- right-handed
- Giving their written informed consent
- Subject who agreed to communicate MRI results to their attending physician
- French Social Security affiliation
Exclusion Criteria:
- any contraindications to pass an fMRI test
- Pregnant woman
